headline: Nvidia, Apple, Big Banks' trading revenues: Trending Tickers
summary: Madison Mills and Interactive Brokers chief strategist Steve Sosnick examine some of today's trending tickers. Nvidia (NVDA) stock is falling after the company warned that new US chip rules on exports to China would cost the company $5.5 billion. Analysts at Bank of America, Piper Sandler, and Raymond James lowered their price targets for the chipmaker stock. Apple's (AAPL) India suppliers shipped $2 billion worth of iPhones in March ahead of US President Trump's tariffs. Wall Street's top financial firms, like JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Goldman Sachs (GS), and Morgan Stanley (MS), saw record-high trading revenue in the first quarter, driven by tariff-fueled market volatility. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Catalysts here.

headline: Big banks push for simpler mortgage rules as housing market slows
summary: Big banks are urging the Trump administration to simplify regulations on loan origination, servicing, and securitization. They hope these reforms could lower mortgage costs and boost lending activity.

headline: 1 Wall Street Analyst Thinks JPMorgan Chase Stock Is Going to $260. Is It a Buy?
summary: One analyst believes JPMorgan Chase (NYSE: JPM) stock isn't the bargain it once was.  CFRA's Kenneth Leon published an update on JPMorgan Chase following the bank's unveiling of its first-quarter results Friday morning.  This was the crux of Leon's price target reduction, according to reports.
